awd_titl_txt: Implementation Project: Transforming Education through Active Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Implementation Projects provide support to Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) to design, implement, study, and assess comprehensive institutional efforts to increase the number of students receiving undergraduate degrees in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) and enhance the quality of their preparation by strengthening STEM education and research. The project at Delaware State University seeks to build on previous successful efforts with a continued focus on improving teaching and learning in mathematics and science towards the goal of enhancing student preparation and performance in STEM fields. Through increased experiential learning and career preparation the project will improve graduation rates and post-graduate outcomes for STEM students and serve as a model for other institutions that serve high minority populations.

The project will utilize evidence-based, high-impact pedagogical practices to improve student learning and outcomes and seeks to transform the STEM educational experience through active and experiential learning, provide professional development for faculty, and further align the training of students to the current and future needs of the STEM workforce. Specific initiatives are to: transform first and second year laboratory courses to introduce students to research through authentic inquiry activities; implement a sustainable peer teaching and learning model focused on developing the leadership skills of advanced students in preparation for graduate school and employment; and bridge the gap of understanding between potential employers and the university in the preparation of STEM students for the workforce. The project will be advised and evaluated for effectiveness by internal and external advisory boards and an evaluator.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The HBCU UP Implementation project, “Transforming Education through Active Learning (TEAL)” at Delaware State University aimed to enhance the STEM educational experience by incorporating active and experiential learning. It focused on professional development for faculty and aligning student training with the current and future demands of the STEM workforce, preparing them to become the next generation of leaders in these fields. The project had three main initiatives:

  1. Redesigning first- and second-year laboratory courses to introduce students to research through authentic inquiry activities.
  2. Implementing a sustainable peer teaching and learning (PTL) model to develop leadership skills in advanced students, preparing them for graduate school and future employment.
  3. Bridging the gap between potential employers and DSU to better prepare students for the workforce.

The COVID-19 pandemic posed significant challenges, necessitating the restructuring of existing activities and the creation of new ones.

A key goal was to support second-year students with peer mentoring and academic assistance to enhance retention and graduation rates among STEM majors. Courses were revamped to increase active learning in several core classes in biology, chemistry, and computer science. While data is still under review, there has been an overall improvement in student performance in these courses and a slight increase in retention rates for second- and third-year students.

Professional development was a major aspect of the project. In collaboration with the Office of Career Services and the Office of Undergraduate Research, Experiential Learning, and Honors (URELAH), STEM students engaged in career preparation and leadership development through workshops, guest speakers, the Hornet Leadership Academy, and the Empower Student Leadership Conference. The Real Talk series featured professionals from diverse STEM careers who shared insights into their personal and professional journeys, helping students build a professional network and find mentorship opportunities. The collaborative work with the TEAL project and URELAH as institutionalized the Hornet Leadership Academy, which is held annually for all students.

Faculty development activities included support for faculty to attend national conferences, enabling those without sufficient resources to present their research and network within the STEM and STEM education communities. To foster a culture of scholarship, the project facilitated an interdisciplinary writing workshop for faculty and graduate students, featuring speakers from the English and Social Sciences departments to encourage collaboration across disciplines. Additionally, a student writing café was organized to provide training and create a support network aimed at enhancing technical writing skills for both graduate and undergraduate students.

Notable outcomes from the project include collaborating with the Office of Student Success to implement EAB Navigate as the CRM for tracking student academic progress and engagement, which aims to enhance retention and graduation rates. Additionally, all program participants received professional development and applied for summer research or technical internships each year. There was also an increase in pass rates for first- and second-year STEM courses, along with greater confidence in both academic and professional skills among students.

 


Last Modified: 10/07/2024
Modified by: Clytrice Watson
